multimedia.caption: The director Michael Apted with, from left, Jackie Bassett, Lynn Johnson and Susan Davis, three of the subjects of his documentary “28 Up” (1984), the fourth in a series that began with “Seven Up!” in 1964 and followed the lives of a group of British people in roughly seven-year intervals.

The director Michael Apted with, from left, Jackie Bassett, Lynn Johnson and Susan Davis, three of the subjects of his documentary “28 Up” (1984), the fourth in a series that began with “Seven Up!” in 1964 and followed the lives of a group of British people in roughly seven-year intervals.

results.title: Michael Apted, Versatile Director Known for ‘Up’ Series, Dies at 79
results.abstract: His output included “Coal Miner’s Daughter” and a James Bond film. But he was best known for his long-running documentary series about life in Britain.
The Netflix series, featuring Lebowitz and directed by Scorsese, offers acerbic commentary and a sense of yearning for a pre-pandemic metropolis.
results.title: Fran Lebowitz and Martin Scorsese Seek a Missing New York in ‘Pretend It’s a City’

results.title: The Force (and a Lenient Disney) Is With ‘Star Wars’ Fan Filmmakers
results.abstract: Whether as tribute or corrective, these movies have proliferated in recent years in part because the studio’s trilogy has inspired strong reactions.

results.abstract: Marvel’s first series for Disney+ is part drama, part homage to vintage sitcoms, following the misfit heroes played by Elizabeth Olsen and Paul Bettany to some weird places.
results.title: Marvel’s Latest Frontier? In ‘WandaVision,’ It’s the Suburbs

results.abstract: “The Rules of the Game,” directed by Jean Renoir, may not seem revolutionary, but thanks to its balance of form and content, it’s an enduring classic.
results.title: What Makes a French Comedy One of the Greatest Films of All Time?

results.title: ‘Grizzly II: Revenge’ Review: Bear Atrocity
results.abstract: Completed after almost four decades in limbo, this unerringly awful sequel places a killer bear in a park filled with clueless concertgoers.

results.title: ‘The Reason I Jump’ Review: Portraits of Autism
results.abstract: Adapted from Naoki Higashida’s book of the same title, this documentary, from Jerry Rothwell, shares portraits of five nonspeaking autistic people on four continents.

results.abstract: When you’ve acted, directed, written, produced, married, divorced, mothered and sold lipstick, what do you do next in America? Host a talk show, of course.
results.title: Drew Barrymore Is Keeping It Clean
‘If Not Now, When?’ Review: Weak Bonds Make for a Flimsy Film
results.abstract: Friends struggle to make sense of romance, purpose and family in this meandering drama.

results.title: ‘Mean Girls’ Won’t Return to Broadway
results.abstract: Adapted by Tina Fey from her 2004 film, the musical played 834 performances. A national tour is expected to resume when theaters reopen.

results.abstract: In her new documentary, Katrine Philp takes us into Good Grief, a facility that helps the very young deal with unspeakable loss.

results.title: ‘My Rembrandt’ Review: Seeing a Dutch Master Everywhere
results.abstract: This documentary looks at art collectors whose interests in Rembrandt have taken on faintly obsessive dimensions.

results.title: Tanya Roberts, a Charlie’s Angel and a Bond Girl, Is Dead at 65
results.abstract: After finding stardom in the 1980s, she fell out of the spotlight until re-emerging in 1998 in the sitcom “That ’70s Show.”

results.title: Publicist for Tanya Roberts Mistakenly Reports Her Death
results.abstract: A miscommunication led to erroneous early reports about the 65-year-old actress, known for her roles in “A View to Kill” and “That ’70s Show.” She later died in a hospital.

results.title: Listen to Rudolph: A New Year Is Both a Comfort and a Fiction
results.abstract: A 1976 TV movie that imagined years as people is a helpful reminder that a new page on the calendar is an arbitrary creation.

results.title: Joan Micklin Silver, Director of ‘Crossing Delancey,’ Dies at 85
results.abstract: She broke barriers for women, directing seven feature films, including “Hester Street” and “Between the Lines,” as well as TV movies.

results.title: Joe Clark, Tough Principal at New Jersey High School, Dies at 82
results.abstract: Bullhorn in hand, he roamed the hallways as he imposed discipline, expelling “miscreants” and restoring order. Morgan Freeman portrayed him in the film “Lean on Me.”

results.title: She’s Starring Opposite Tom Hanks. She’d Never Heard of Him.
results.abstract: Helena Zengel is a giggly, chatty 12-year-old, whose movie roles take her into psychological territory that even adults would find tough.
